title: Forces of nature: six of Britain’s most breathtaking waterfalls | Life and style | The Guardian
text:
Tuesday 7 February 2017 06.30 GMT Last modified on Tuesday 7 February 2017 06.32 GMT Falling Foss , near Sleights, North Yorkshire Perfect for swimming – in summer ... Falling Foss. Photograph: Alamy 
Context colours the overall impression of a waterfall, and Falling Foss is a good example. An idyllic woodland walk alongside May Beck brings you to the 10-metre-high falls, which stutters beautifully down a hunk of black rock into a swimmable pool. Nearby is the Hermitage, a hollowed-out boulder where it is said a hermit once lived. In summer, there is a good tea garden, too . Thornton Force , Ingleton, North Yorkshire Worth the fee ... Thornton Force in full flow. Photograph: Garry Ridsdale/Getty Images/Robert Harding World Imagery 
I don’t approve of paying to see waterfalls – not unless the ticket office is a 13th-century pub, as in the case of Hardraw Force . You wouldn’t pay to see a mountain, would you? “There, that’s Ben Nevis. That’ll be £1.50, please.” However, this 4.5-mile trail is worth the whopping £6 entry fee. A lovely circuit, beautifully kept and managed, it takes you around nine falls – including Thornton Force, one of England’s finest – on two rivers, the Twiss and the Doe. Pistyll Rhyd-y-meinciau ( Rhiwargor waterfalls ), Lake Vyrnwy, Powys Great picnic spot ... Pistyll Rhyd-y-meinciau. Photograph: Alamy 
This is not as well known as its neighbour Pistyll Rhaeadr, but it has the edge in grandeur and atmosphere. From a car park at the northern extremity of Lake Vyrnwy, take the trail for about a mile up to a spectacular series of cascades on the River Eiddew. It makes a great picnic spot, plus there are a few deeper pools for summer dips. Down below, Lake Vyrnwy is a lovely nine-mile circuit on bicycle; bikes can be hired at the village by the dam at the other end of the lake. Mealt Falls, Skye A waterfall in a different league ... Mealt Falls. Photograph: Alamy 
Waterfalls that leap off cliffs into the sea have a special place in my heart. There are two I like in North Yorkshire (near Bogle Hole and Hayburn Wyke) that never amount to much, but I still love them. Mealt Falls on Skye, however, is in a different league. This is Milford Sound standard: a great, galloping gush of water chucking itself 55 metres off a precipice into the Minch . You need to abseil or kayak to get the best panorama, but the viewing platform, close to the A855, makes things simple. Sgwd yr Eira, Brecon Beacons Veil of water ... Sgwd yr Eira. Photograph: Richard Collins/Getty Images 
In terms of quantity and quality, the Four Falls Trail in the Brecon Beacons takes some beating. A 5.5-mile walk takes you through a series of falls, culminating in the best of the lot, Sgwd yr Eira. This veil of water allows walkers to get behind it for a Last of the Mohicans moment. Expect to get very wet. Gaping Gill , near Clapham, North Yorkshire Worth the wait ... Gaping Gill. Photograph: Alamy 
This is one to save up for summer: an underground fall that requires a gut-churning descent on a wire into a cavern large enough to contain York Minster. There, you get a perfect view of Fell Beck dropping 100 metres through a narrow hole into a huge space below. Local cavers set up a winch during summer. There are long queues, but it is worth the wait.
